revised_title: Evolutionary Consequences of Cytoplasmically Inherited Feminizing Factors in Host Populations
tldr: The authors develop a model to analyze the population and evolutionary consequences of parasitic sex ratio distortion in host populations with cytoplasmically inherited feminizing factors. They distinguish between the processes of transmission and expression and find that the evolutionarily stable host sex ratio will be biased towards the non-transmitting sex, provided that transmission and feminization efficiencies are not both 100%. This may lead to monogeny, where uninfected females produce only the non-transmitting sex.
scientific_discipline: Biology and Life Sciences > Evolutionary Biology
